page.title: 16A Limestone Quarry
page.content: On a working day at the quarry, the first step in retrieving limestone is to drill into the rock face. When the hole has been formed, explosives are placed into the hollow area. In every blast a quantity of 10-15,000 tonnes of stone shatters from the rock side. The limestone is put into a crusher which breaks down the rocks and crushes them into different sizes. Limestone can be put onto farming land to counter acidity. It is used in road construction, brick and slab making. When bitumen is added to limestone, it forms tarmac to be used for resurfacing roads. Wet mix and lean mix both use water and cement mixed together with limestone. The Tarmac Company have a fleet of 50 lorries, each capable of carrying 16-20 tonnes of limestone, mostly used in a 80 kilometre radius for road building.
